message: It was great to have my family with me for the swearing in of the 115th Congress. It’s an honor to represent San Antonians and our city in the House of Representatives.
I’m looking forward to a productive Congress with the Congressional Hispanic Caucus. It’s an honor to serve as our organization’s First Vice Chair.

The intelligence community has determined that President Putin ordered the Russian government to manipulate our nation’s presidential election through an extensive cyber operation and influence campaign. This assessment reinforces previous findings presented to the American people.     U.S. intelligence officials are highly-skilled individuals whose mission is to protect the American people and our nation’s interests around the world, often at great personal sacrifice. Congressional leadership from both parties have voiced their strong confidence in these brave public servants’ work. Our President-elect’s repeated denigration of their efforts is troubling and dangerous.    Congress now has a responsibility to act on this report. I support the Obama Administration’s recent sanctions against Russia and encourage the creation of an independent, bipartisan commission to focus on this matter. Attempts to undermine our democracy and Americans’ confidence in the electoral process will not be tolerated.  You can read the full, declassified intelligence report that was released today here: https://www.dni.gov/files/documents/ICA_2017_01.pdf

The Texas Bathroom Bill demonizes innocent people and would badly hurt our Texas economy. The Texas legislature should focus on creating jobs, improving schools. I'm proud of the Texas business community that's taken a strong stand against it.
President-elect Trump’s Attorney General nominee Sen. Jeff Sessions’ confirmation hearing with the Senate Judiciary Committee is this morning. Here are four facts about him:

As the 2017 Texas legislative session begins today, lawmakers should address our state’s most pressing issues: creating jobs, improving schools, fixing our broken foster care system, and protecting Texas women’s access to healthcare. Over the past few years, Texas has slid in job creation compared to other states. Pursuing the discriminatory ‘bathroom bill’ could result in Texas losing up to $8.5 billion and more than 100,000 jobs, according to the Texas Association of Business. The Legislature should seek to expand opportunity, not stifle Texans’ ability to pursue their goals and contribute to our state.
It’s an honor to be the new CHCI Chair. I look forward to working with my fellow Congressional Hispanic Caucus members to develop the next generation of leaders in our nation.

The Republicans’ campaign to repeal the Affordable Care Act without offering a replacement plan would hurt millions of American families who rely on the law for access to lifesaving care. Eliminating the ACA would take away Medicare benefits for seniors, raise middle class Americans’ taxes, and devastate individuals with preexisting conditions who wouldn’t be able to find insurance without the law. We should work to refine and improve the ACA, not irresponsibly gut it.   The overwhelming majority of my constituents who have called and written me about the ACA want the law to remain in place. I will fight to protect the Affordable Care Act unless a viable improvement is presented.

We must determine who exactly was involved in the Russia hack and respond strongly to prevent future attacks. Today I discussed this issue on MSNBC, as well as the newly-announced investigation into the FBI’s actions during the election.

For Texas to reach its economic potential, all our students must have the opportunity to achieve educational and professional success. At the Texas Tribune's symposium on race this morning, I discussed ways to expand access to pre-k, improve college graduation rates, and close the achievement gap in Texas’ schools.
May the words and peaceful actions of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. inspire us today and every day to work for greater justice in our nation.

Today, our city lays to rest a beacon of compassion. Archbishop Patrick Flores served the San Antonio community for more than two decades. He devoted his life to helping the poor, standing up for workers, and increasing educational opportunities for young people. My prayers are with his family during this difficult time.
Today I joined SAReads to discuss the power of reading and importance of getting books in our kids’ hands. Together, we can increase literacy in San Antonio.

Every American should respect the office of the presidency and the fact that Donald Trump will be the 45th President of the United States. But winning an election does not mean a man can show contempt for millions of Americans and then expect those very people to celebrate him.     I come from a family and a place, Texas, where respect is a fundamental value – respect for people regardless of what they look like, where they were born, or whether they share your view of the world. Donald Trump has shown an utter lack of respect for so many Americans. His attack on civil rights hero John Lewis is the latest example.    I will not attend this year’s inauguration ceremony. However, I will be in Washington to greet constituents who are traveling to our nation's capital for the proceedings. I respect their choice to attend.
I joined Port San Antonio to celebrate Kelly Field’s centennial and highlight the former base’s 100 years of economic contributions to our city.
Welcome back to Texas.
NA

While some in Washington only highlight and often exaggerate the negative aspects the U.S.-Mexico border, the region actually generates incredible economic energy for our nation. San Antonio alone has annual exports to Mexico exceeding $3.5 billion. I joined several of my colleagues for a hearing on business at the southern border, and am grateful that Robert McKinley from the UTSA Institute for Economic Development attended to share his expertise.
If you’re in Washington, D.C., join me this evening at the Newseum  for a discussion with BuzzFeed Politics about the big issues facing our nation.

The border wall is a lazy and ineffective security strategy. In fact, recent polls show that 59 percent of the American people disagree with building a wall along our nation’s southern border. The wall could cost up to $25 billion to construct – that’s American taxpayer money that could be used more effectively elsewhere, like in our schools or on crumbling roads.    President Trump’s actions represent a hostility toward Mexico, one of our oldest allies and trading partners. He is driving Mexico into China’s arms. I expect that whatever President Trump takes away from Mexico, China will step in to offer. I am concerned about the harmful effects these measures will have on San Antonio, Dallas, the Rio Grande Valley, and other places in Texas that sell so many goods to Mexico. American jobs depend on that commerce.    The immigration-related executive orders signed today are bad for our economy, for our communities, and for our nation’s overall security strategy.

Japan is a critical security and economic partner to the United States. The new administration should build on the progress President Obama made in strengthening our nations’ relationship and demonstrate the United States’ commitment to our friend. Thank you to the Japan-America Society of Washington DC (JASWDC) and the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace for hosting a thoughtful and timely discussion on the future of the U.S.-Japan alliance.
Join Rep. Lloyd Doggett and me this Saturday afternoon to talk about how the Affordable Care Act has helped folks in San Antonio and across Texas gain health coverage.
Today is Holocaust Remembrance Day, a sorrowful reminder of the need to vigilantly combat anti-Semitism and all intolerance.

The Affordable Care Act saves lives. Today, San Antonians shared the ways the law has helped their families access the care they need, and Rep. Lloyd Doggett and I reiterated that we are fighting to protect Texans’ coverage in Congress. I’m grateful for the work EnrollSA and Daughters of Charity Services of San Antonio have done to help folks get covered in our city. If you need health insurance, there’s still time to enroll. Go to Healthcare.gov by Tuesday, January 31 to find a plan that works for you.
President Trump's ban on Muslim refugees betrays American values while undermining national security and economic prosperity. It is wrong.
Any San Antonians who need help for family members affected by President Trump's executive order on refugees, please call my office at 210-348-8216 or 202-225-3236.
Today we honor Fred Korematsu, who fought the unjust internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II.
I joined the Texas Association of School Boards to discuss ways we can work together to strengthen public education in our state and create greater opportunity for our kids.

Contrary to what the Governor proclaimed in his State of the State address today, our state government is on the wrong track. The Texas economy has slipped from third to 21st in the nation. Greg Abbott and Republican leaders have stayed silent while Donald Trump has bullied and threatened Texas companies. They haven’t taken a stand against the President’s proposed tax on imports, which would cripple Texas’ economy, or the border wall idea, which the majority of Texans have rejected. And they have allowed corruption to run rampant, reserving sweetheart contracts for friends, effectively discouraging other businesses from competing for work from the government.   Young, vulnerable Texans continue to suffer. Republican leaders have yet to take meaningful action on improving our neglected child protective services.    Finally, despite tougher economic times for our state, Republican leadership has insisted on pushing bathroom legislation rather than focusing on jobs, schools, or healthcare access. The state’s leadership does not share the priorities of Texas families or Texas businesses.
Black History Month is a reminder of the work we must pursue every month to make our nation a fairer, more equitable, and more just place.
Congress must take action if President Trump intentionally disobeyed a court's order on the Muslim ban. I discussed with Chris Hayes:

Over the past couple days, I’ve raised concerns that the executive branch may have intentionally violated the judiciary. I’m glad that the Department of Homeland Security’s Office of Inspector General will be reviewing DHS’ adherence to court orders in its implementation of the recent Muslim ban executive order. I look forward to their report to Congress.

The President used the same unhinged, hostile approach with Australia as he has with our friend Mexico. This is no way to treat an ally that has been a longstanding economic and security partner, both globally and in the Asia-Pacific.

The Trump Administration is going to extreme lengths to put Russian interests above the United States’. Today, U.S. tech companies can do business with Russia’s security service and they couldn’t yesterday. That “technical correction” to our sanctions rewards Russia. This is bad national security policy.  It is unfathomable that our government would ease sanctions, not tighten them, after our intelligence community concluded that Russia interfered in our most recent election. Furthermore, both the House and Senate Intelligence Committees are currently reviewing the totality of Russia’s role in our electoral process. Changing policy mid-inquiry is reckless and irresponsible. Allowing U.S. companies to do business with the Russian intelligence service (FSB) rewards Russia for its nefarious behavior and emboldens Putin to act out in the future. Just this week, Russian-backed rebels have renewed their fighting in Ukraine.    I will work with any member of Congress to swiftly reinstate and strengthen these sanctions.
Why the Congress must censure the President if he purposely disobeyed court orders regarding the Muslim ban.

The United States and Israel are close, committed allies, but Prime Minister Netanyahu’s recent comments regarding President Trump’s proposed border wall were distressing and outside the scope of our nations’ relationship. While the Prime Minister and President Rivlin have since clarified the comments’ intended meaning, members of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus still felt it important to voice our concern in a letter to Israeli Ambassador Ron Dermer.

Because of a federal court order, the Department of Homeland Security is halting its enforcement of the Muslim Ban and the State Department is reversing its provisional revocation of visas. Despite his disagreement with the judge who made this decision, President Trump is constitutionally obligated to abide by the court order. All members of Congress, regardless of political party, should insist he does so. Preserving our nation’s separation of powers and system of checks and balances supersedes partisan politics.

I'm asking The United States Department of Justice to investigate whether President Trump and his Administration violated court orders related to the Muslim travel ban executive order. If the President did in fact act unconstitutionally, the Congress should censure him. If he violates the Constitution again, the Congress should work to remove him from office and prevent a constitutional crisis. My remarks on the House floor:
I urge my colleagues to join me in asking The United States Department of Justice to investigate if President Trump violated court orders related to his Muslim travel ban.
I worry about Attorney General Sessions’ commitment to protecting all Americans’ civil liberties. We must remain vigilant and defend our rights.

I’m glad the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals has ruled that the President’s travel ban executive order will remain on hold. The administration will likely challenge today’s decision, and I will continue to follow the case closely as it progresses through the courts.
I’m joining Erin Burnett OutFront in the 6:00 pm CST hour to discuss the decision on President Trump’s travel ban.
No President is above the law. I discussed the 9th Circuit Court's ruling on President Trump’s travel ban with Erin Burnett OutFront:

I am concerned about the ICE raids in Texas. I have been informed by ICE that the agency’s San Antonio field office has launched a targeted operation in South and Central Texas as part of Operation Cross Check. I'm asking ICE to clarify whether these individuals are in fact dangerous, violent threats to our communities, and not people who are here peacefully raising families and contributing to our state. I will continue to monitor this situation.

I strongly condemn North Korea’s missile test this morning. The regime’s repeated violation of UN Security Council resolutions threatens stability in the Pacific region and further isolates Pyongyang from the nations of the world. The United States remains firmly committed to our allies, including Japan South Korea, whose security we will defend. The Trump Administration needs to clearly signal the United States’ disapproval of this act, and I urge the UN Security Council to convene a meeting and develop a response.

National Security Advisor Michael Flynn’s resignation is a step in the right direction, but many questions remain. Who associated with the Trump Administration knew the details of Flynn’s conversations with Russian officials, and when did they know them? After the Department of Justice warned the Trump transition team that Flynn was vulnerable to Russian blackmail, why did the President take the risk of appointing him to such a sensitive, influential position in the White House? If media reports had not exposed the nature of General Flynn’s call with Russia, would he still be the President’s National Security Advisor today?   Investigations must take place to determine how severely this administration has compromised our nation’s security. Congress and the American people deserve to know the full extent of Russia’s ties with the White House and involvement in the 2016 election.

Teachers of all grade levels in this nation go above and beyond to give our kids the best possible education, sometimes even paying for school supplies out of their own pockets. While current law allows K-12 teachers to receive a tax deduction for that work-related expense, early educators are excluded from the benefit. I’ve introduced legislation called the Pre-K Teacher Parity Act, which would allow all teachers to receive the same compensation for buying their students’ supplies. You can read more about the bill here:
Any Americans who conspired with the Russian hackers should be prosecuted to the full extent of the law, no matter how high up the trail goes.

Studies show that kids who complete high-quality pre-kindergarten programs find greater academic and career success than those who don’t. I founded the bipartisan Congressional Pre-K Caucus with Congresswoman Katherine Clark and Congressman Tom Cole to help expand access to early education across the country. Today we joined friends from Sesame Workshop and PBS KIDS to kick off the Caucus for the 115th Congress and discuss the importance of early learning.
Why the Congress must determine whether any Americans conspired with the Russians who interfered in our elections:

Today marks 75 years since the signing of Executive Order 9066, which authorized the internment of Japanese Americans during World War II. This was a dark moment in our nation’s history – one we must never repeat. On this anniversary, we recognize the important work of civil rights advocate Fred Korematsu, and remember that it is never acceptable to discriminate against individuals based on their race, religion, or national origin. The United States is a nation of immigrants that is stronger for its diversity.  I am pleased that today, our nation enjoys a strong, forward-looking partnership with our friend Japan. Working together, we can make the world a more peaceful, secure, and just place.
I'm praying for Houston and the safety of everyone at Ben Taub Hospital. Thank you to the first responders who are on the scene.

The memos that Department of Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly issued today confirm that the President’s aggressive immigration executive orders are being set into motion. While the Obama Administration prioritized the removal of violent criminals, the Trump Administration has deemed almost all undocumented immigrants – with the exception of some DACA recipients – priorities for deportation. The door is open for families to be ripped apart, separating hardworking parents from their children. Additionally, increasing the number of immigrant detention facilities, reinstating the controversial Secure Communities program, expanding the number of individuals subject to expedited removal, and referring parents who brought their children to the United States for criminal prosecution undermine our national security and our economic might. These costly measures and the administration’s insistence on building an ineffective, multi-billion dollar border wall are not efficient uses of our resources.    I agree that we must remove violent individuals who entered the United States illegally. But in targeting an exponentially larger segment of the immigrant population, the President’s extreme orders make our country less safe. Instead, we should pursue sensible, comprehensive reforms that Americans across the political spectrum support.
After meeting with ICE Acting Director Thomas Homan last week, I shared my concerns about the Trump Administration’s expanded deportation efforts with Chris Hayes.
We must fully and fairly investigate the extent of communication President Trump’s White House and campaign staff have had with Russian officials.

I’ve just returned from a trip to Japan and South Korea, two of the United States’ critical security and economic allies. While there, I met with several government officials, including Japanese Prime Minister Shinzō Abe and Speaker of Korea's National Assembly Chung Sye-kyun, to discuss ways we can strengthen our nations’ bonds. San Antonio has particularly strong ties with Japan and Japanese businesses, and I reiterated our city’s commitment to our Asian partners. As a founding co-chair of the U.S.-Japan Caucus in Congress, I will continue to create opportunities for U.S. legislators to meet with our Japanese and Korean counterparts. The greater our understanding of each other’s priorities, policymaking processes, and customs, the more effectively we can work together to make the world a more secure, prosperous place.
Please join me for a Town Hall meeting in San Antonio on the evening of Monday, March 6. All are welcome. More details to come.
White House staff pressuring FBI officials to cover up a story in the press is yet another allegation against the Trump Administration requiring investigation.
The Trump Administration’s aggressive immigration orders endanger our civil liberties.

The details for my upcoming town hall have been set. Join me at 6:30 p.m. next Monday, March 6, at Memorial High School in San Antonio. I look forward to hearing your feedback and answering your questions. You can RSVP to attend here: RSVP.Castro@mail.house.gov. Everyone welcome.
I'm calling back constituents who have reached out to my office recently. Cleaning my desk next.

If you’re a high school student interested in attending one of our nation’s service academies, I encourage you to come to an information session this Sunday, March 5, from 2:00 to 4:00 p.m. at UTSA’s main campus. Representatives from the academies and members of my staff will be there to provide information about the nomination process.
Separating mothers and children who are fleeing violence is unconscionable.
All are welcome to attend my town hall tomorrow evening at 6:30 p.m. in Memorial High School’s cafeteria. If you’re unable to join us in person, you can watch the discussion online here:
If you can't join my town hall in person this evening, watch here beginning at 6:30pm CST:
Thank you to everyone who came to my town hall tonight, your voices matter.

Increasing access to high quality pre-kindergarten should be a federal, state, and local priority. Investing in our youngest children's learning is an investment in the next generation of American workers and in America's economy. This morning I discussed the future of early education and childcare in our nation with Ron Brownstein at AtlanticLIVE's Next America forum.

On International Women’s Day and every day, we should push for greater female empowerment, stand up for women’s rights, and celebrate the inspiring women in our communities. More work must be done to ensure all people, regardless of gender, have equal opportunity in life.
With each new revelation of contacts between Trump staff and Russian officials, the Intelligence Committees' investigations grow more urgent.

UTSA - The University of Texas at San Antonio's cybersecurity leadership inspired legislation of mine that passed the House of Representatives during the previous Congress. The bill allows non-profit entities, including universities, to work more closely with the Department of Homeland Security to address cybersecurity risks and incidents at the state and local level. I reintroduced the bipartisan legislation in the House this week, and Senator John Cornyn reintroduced it in the Senate. I'm hopeful the measure becomes law.

President Trump and congressional Republicans have proposed a healthcare plan that will result in 24 million fewer Americans with insurance in 2026. Congress should fine tune the Affordable Care Act, not put millions of lives at risk with a seriously flawed piece of rushed legislation.

I am very saddened to learn of Kika de la Garza’s passing. His life was one of committed service – first in the Navy and Army, then in the Texas Legislature, and later in the U.S. Congress. He worked tirelessly to make life better for Texans, pushing for greater educational opportunity and federal support for farmers and ranchers. De la Garza consistently stood up for marginalized people in our nation and supported historic civil rights legislation that propelled important progress in our society. A son of the Valley, he deeply understood U.S.-Mexico relations and helped foster closer, more constructive ties between our nations.  Kika de la Garza was one of the exceptional Texans whose work inspired me to pursue a career in public service. Our state and nation benefitted tremendously from his lifetime of service and sacrifice. My prayers are with his family and loved ones in this difficult time.
The revised travel ban still violates the Constitution and our American values.

There are so many real and pressing issues that Texans want to see addressed – struggling public schools, our state’s sliding economic ranking, and the rape kit backlog, to name a few. Instead of taking on those matters today, the Texas Senate wasted its time and passed the discriminatory bathroom bill, SB 6. I hope that Speaker Straus and the Texas House stand up for students and put aside the legislation.

I joined NPR's Weekend Edition this morning to discuss the President’s unsubstantiated wiretapping claims and the House Intelligence Committee’s upcoming hearing on Russia’s interference in the 2016 election.
I’ll be on ABC’s This Week tomorrow morning to discuss the House Intelligence Committee’s hearing on Russian interference in the 2016 election. In San Antonio, tune in at 9:00 a.m. CDT.

Tomorrow, the House Intelligence Committee holds a public hearing as part of our investigation into Russia’s interference in the 2016 election. I joined ABC's This Week to discuss the committee’s work and the potential consequences of the President’s baseless wiretapping claims.
You can watch the livestream of today’s House Intelligence Committee hearing on Russia’s interference in the 2016 U.S. election beginning at 9:00 a.m. CDT here:

Two portions of today’s public House Intelligence Committee hearing stood out as particularly significant. First, the American people learned that the FBI is investigating possible links between the Trump campaign and Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. election. Second, both FBI Director Comey and National Security Agency Director Rogers confirmed that neither of them have seen any evidence to support the President’s claims that President Obama wiretapped Trump Tower.    I look forward to the Intelligence Committee’s bipartisan investigation moving forward, building on what we discussed today. We need to determine not only the extent of Russia’s attempts to undermine our election and democracy, but also whether any Americans participated in those efforts. I am confident that with continued cooperation, our investigation will go wherever the evidence leads.
The House Intelligence Committee will follow the facts wherever they lead to find the truth and prevent future attacks on our elections. My comments to Chris Cuomo on CNN's New Day.
My prayers are with the British people after today’s deadly attacks in London. The United States stands firmly with our ally, the United Kingdom.

House Intelligence Committee Chairman Nunes’ actions today compromise the effectiveness of the committee. Speaking to both the media and the White House prior to conferring with fellow members undermines the committee’s ability to do its job and provide appropriate oversight.   As recently as this morning, I have spoken positively about the bipartisan nature in which Chairman Nunes and the entire House Intelligence Committee has operated. The Chairman’s actions today represent an abrupt and clear departure from that posture.   Scripture reminds us that a person cannot serve two masters. Chairman Nunes can either lead this committee to pursue the truth or choose to serve as an advocate for President Trump.

I enjoyed meeting with an impressive group of young people from Japan visiting Washington with the TOMODACHI Women’s Leadership Program. I believe that the people-to-people connections formed through educational, business, and cultural exchange play an important role in strengthening the United States and Japan’s strategic partnership.
Texans, these are 10 things you’ll either lose or have to pay jacked up prices for if the Republicans' healthcare bill passes today:

Today, members of Congress from across the country realized that Republicans' healthcare bill would hurt their constituents. Millions of people would have lost their coverage, including more than 660,000 Texans. The legislation also would have resulted in lost, or jacked up prices for, essential care like emergency room visits, prescription drugs, and pregnancy care. Congress should work in a bipartisan way to fix our current healthcare system.
The Trump Administration’s proposal to cut funding to the U.S. Department of State and US Agency for International Development (USAID) by nearly a third would be irresponsible and short-sighted.

Chairman Nunes’ actions have compromised his ability to lead the House Intelligence Committee’s investigation into Russia’s attack on our 2016 election. He should step aside. I discuss with Chris Hayes:
Saddened to learn of the terrible crash near Garner State Park. My prayers are with the victims and their loved ones.
Today we celebrate Cesar Chavez and remember the power we all have, working together, to advance civil rights and spur positive change.
It was great to meet with so many Texans this week, like folks with the Texas Farm Bureau, Texas Cattle Feeders Association, and NAHREP The National Association of Hispanic Real Estate Professionals.
Tonight I spoke with future leaders at the Hispanic Law Students Association banquet in Houston.

This evening, I’m leading a discussion on the House floor about the Trump Administration’s irresponsible proposed international affairs budget cuts with Ranking Member Eliot Engel, Rep. Albio Sires, and other House Committee on Foreign Affairs Democrats. You can watch our remarks starting at about 5:00 p.m. CT here:

The Trump Administration’s proposed cuts to the U.S. international affairs budget would be an abdication of global leadership. If America retreats from the global stage, other powers like China will step in to fill that void and exert their influence. We cannot afford for that to happen. You can watch my remarks on the House floor here:

North Korea’s continued missile tests violate UN Security Council resolutions and threaten regional stability. The United States is fully committed to defending our allies in the region, including Japan and South Korea. Nothing good will come from the Kim regime’s reckless hostility. President Trump must make addressing North Korea’s aggression a top priority during President Xi’s visit this week.

Congratulations to Clark High School student Lemuel Wilson for developing my district’s Congressional App Challenge winning submission, “Game of Flags.” Lemuel’s engaging app helps young people learn the flags of U.S. states. Thank you to all the talented San Antonio students who submitted their great ideas!

Today, House Intelligence Committee Chairman Devin Nunes announced he will step aside from leading the committee's investigation into Russia. As the chairman has said, his decision is in the best interests of the committee and its investigation. I am hopeful that under the leadership of Mike Conaway we can move forward in a bipartisan way that gets to the truth of Russia’s interference in our election and whether any Americans were involved.

Over the years, states like Texas have failed to prioritize pre-k, causing young children to miss out on critical early learning and fall behind their peers in other states and countries. Today, I introduced the Pre-K for USA Act, which allows localities and educational entities to bypass state governments and secure the federal resources they need to support prekindergarten programs. You can read more about the legislation here:

Tonight, the United States launched missiles at an airfield in Syria. The Assad regime’s repeated chemical attacks on its own citizens are war crimes and indisputably horrific, but Congress plays an important role in authorizing military force. I continue to believe that Congress must authorize any additional use of force against the Syrian government.
Happy birthday, Dolores Huerta. Thank you for your decades of leadership standing up for justice and civil rights for all Americans.
Horrible news coming out of San Bernardino today. My prayers are with everyone in the community there.
Wishing all who celebrate a joyous Passover!

Today, a federal court reaffirmed that the Texas Legislature passed our state’s voter ID law with the intent to discriminate. Texans will continue to be disenfranchised until this law is permanently repealed.

The Social Security Administration office on E. Southcross is closed for renovation and expected to reopen at the end of July. If you need in-person assistance, other San Antonio offices are located at the following addresses:   • 727 E. Cesar E. Chavez Blvd., San Antonio, Texas 78206 • 402 Isom Rd., San Antonio, Texas 78216 • 411 Richland Hills Dr., San Antonio, Texas 78245  If you have other questions regarding your Social Security benefits, please call my office at 210-348-8216 and we’ll help direct you to the resources you need.

The Venezuelan government’s crackdown on protesters and political opponents is troubling. The United States and other nations in the Americas must strongly urge President Maduro to respect the rights of his people and permit free and fair elections to take place.
My family and I wish you and yours a very happy Easter!
This week is National Park Week, a great time to visit the beautiful San Antonio Missions National Historical Park.

San Antonio high school students still have time to submit entries to the Congressional Art Competition! If you have questions about the contest, please call my office at 210-348-8216. You can also check out previous winners' work and find helpful information on the competition’s website here: http://www.house.gov/content/educate/art_competition/

Earth Day is a great occasion to celebrate Texas’ renewable energy leadership. Texas is the top wind energy producer in the country, generating more wind energy than the next three states combined. San Antonio is ranked eighth in the country for solar energy production and is the top producing city in our state. Solar and wind energy create good jobs for Texans and help keep our environment clean, benefitting both our economy and planet.
On Holocaust Remembrance Day, we mourn the loss and honor the memory of the 11 million people, including 6 million Jews, who were senselessly killed during the Holocaust.

The United States must be an unwavering global leader or risk opening the door for China’s accelerated rise. I enjoyed joining the Asia Society Policy Institute and the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies | SAIS for a discussion on U.S.-Asia policy during the Trump Administration’s first 100 days.
I met Alice through Tuesday's Children and was glad to spend some time with her on Take Our Children to Work Day.

When a veteran is in crisis, every minute counts. I’ve introduced legislation to make it easier for veterans to connect quickly and directly with the Veterans Crisis Line and access the help they need.
Thank you to the Association of Latino Administrators and Superintendents - ALAS for all the work you do educating and inspiring students across our nation.
My prayers are with the El Paso ISD community and everyone affected by today’s tragic bus crash in West Texas.
Thank you to the first responders who assisted after the devastating tornadoes in Northeast Texas this weekend. I’m praying for all the folks who were in the paths of those storms.
Happy Decision Day to college-bound high school seniors in San Antonio! Congratulations on all your success, and best of luck as you embark on the next chapter of your education.
Horrific news out of UT Austin today. My prayers are with the families of the victim and those who were injured in the stabbing there.

To counter North Korea’s aggression, we must take additional steps to cut off the Kim regime’s access to resources that support its ballistic missile and nuclear programs. I spoke in favor of legislation that updates and expands the range of sanctions available for the United States to use against people or entities that violate U.S. sanction laws and United Nations Security Council resolutions regarding North Korea.

The state government in Texas has failed our children. Kids in the foster care system sleep in Child Protective Services offices, and young victims of sex trafficking are sent to jail because there’s nowhere else for them to go. Since state leaders don’t care enough to invest in these children’s wellbeing, I’m hopeful that legislation in the U.S. House can provide vulnerable Texas kids with support they desperately need.

Republicans’ healthcare bill lets state leaders in Austin abandon sick Texans. The legislation allows states to permit insurance companies to get rid of essential health benefits and charge people who have preexisting conditions, like cancer and diabetes, extremely high premiums for coverage. I’m voting against the legislation.

Republicans’ healthcare bill lets state leaders in Austin abandon Texans who have preexisting conditions. States will have the option to allow insurance companies to inflict devastatingly high premiums on people suffering from ailments like cancer, heart disease, epilepsy, diabetes, asthma, and Parkinson’s disease. After allowing foster children to sleep in CPS offices and sex trafficking victims to spend the night in prison, I don’t trust our Governor to do the right thing and look out for sick folks in our state. I voted against the AHCA.

The United States and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) share tremendous economic and security interests. I’ve co-founded the Congressional Caucus on ASEAN to help deepen the United States’ strategic partnerships with ASEAN member countries. It was a pleasure to meet with ASEAN foreign ministers visiting Washington, D.C. and discuss our nations’ mutual priorities and opportunities for greater collaboration. Thank you to CSIS | Center for Strategic & International Studies and the US-ASEAN Business Council for hosting the discussion.

Yesterday, the House of Representatives passed legislation that would significantly change healthcare in our country – for the worse. If the Senate passes this bill and President Trump signs it into law, state leaders will have the option to allow insurance providers to jack up prices for people with pre-existing conditions and stop covering essential health services altogether. H.R. 1761, the Protecting Against Child Exploitation Act,  is a perfect example of legislative dysfunction. The bill aims to close a loophole that allows some child pornographers to escape prosecution by arguing over intent. OK, sounds like a good idea. But Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee points out a big loophole in the new bill that would allow for the prosecution of consenting teenagers who are sexting each other (i.e., they are in a relationship and only sharing the images with each other) to be charged for child pornography and prosecuted to serve a 15 year minimum sentence. Again, this includes a boyfriend/girlfriend sharing images only with each other. So I figured, OK, I'm sure the bill's author will accept Rep. Jackson Lee’s amendment, close the loophole and we can all support the bill. No. Instead he argues basically that no prosecutor would ever charge people in that situation. Yes, somebody will. Or they'll use the possibility of charging as heavy leverage to get something out of a defendant. So now we face a choice: Vote YES for what is now a bad piece of legislation that creates as many (if not more) problems than it solves or vote NO and be accused sometime next October of going easy on child pornographers. That's Congress, folks. I voted NO. I am in my eighth term in public service, all in the minority party.   So why didn't they just take Rep. Jackson Lee’s amendment? Maybe they see no problem sending a teenage couple to jail for fifteen years for sexting. Maybe because they know they already have the votes needed to pass the bill and can just do it their way. But more likely, it's because the majority party knows it can force people in the other party to either go along or take a "bad" vote. The quest to create wedges (by the majority) and the politics of self-preservation and ambition (by the minority) lead to bad public policy. All of us have fallen for it – both parties do it in legislatures across the country.   I love representing my hometown and always have. But there are times when people ask me, "what's the worst part of the job?" More than the hamster wheel of fundraising, ping-pong travel between D.C. and home or anything else it is this cycle of wedging and C-Y-A politics that corrodes the American Congress. The problem with Congress is not that there is too much legitimate policy disagreement, people are legitimately pro-life or pro-choice; pro vouchers or against them, etc. The more pernicious problem is that, as in the case of H.R. 1761, the Protecting Against Child Exploitation Act, disagreement is preserved, manufactured, or coerced for political purposes, even when agreement is well within reach. So next year, if they say the 51 of us who voted no are sympathetic to child pornographers, remember our conversation.

Tonight, I’ll be pushing for the passage of four of my amendments as part of the House appropriations process. One of my amendments would provide an additional $5 million to equip Customs and Border Protection agents with body cameras. Another of my amendments would provide $10 million to supply Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents with body camera technology. Body-worn cameras are not a cure-all, but they improve officers’ public interactions, de-escalate conflicts, and increase trust in law enforcement. Local law enforcement agencies around the country are adopting body cameras – federal law enforcement agencies should do the same.   My third amendment would prevent the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) from entering into contracts with privatized immigration detention facilities in FY 2018. A DHS study found that privatized facilities have staffing deficiencies, subpar medical care, and inefficient abuse reporting systems.   My final amendment seeks to protect Rangel, Pickering, and Payne fellowships from elimination. These fellowship programs help under-represented minorities serve in the U.S. diplomatic corps and strengthen our foreign service.   I’ll keep you updated on whether or not these measures pass.

Yet again, President Trump has signaled to the rest of the world that the United States no longer wishes to lead. Failing to certify Iran’s compliance with the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) moves the United States closer to abrogating the agreement, which would dramatically increase the risk of Iran moving forward in developing nuclear weapons and lead to the further destabilization of the Middle East. There are many aspects of Iran’s behavior that the United States must confront, including its development of ballistic missiles and support for terrorist groups. The United States Congress has consistently addressed these challenges through legislation. Undermining the JCPOA, a successful effort to limit Iran’s nuclear weapons capability, makes it much harder for our allies around the world to trust us when we approach them to work on these other issues.  Today’s announcement is the latest of President Trump’s many missteps that have severely damaged the United States’ credibility around the world. After wavering on this landmark agreement, why would any country enter into a high-stakes deal with the United States in the future? How does the President expect to marshal support for plans to address North Korea, Syria, or any other crisis after demonstrating his willingness to withdraw from an agreement led and negotiated by the United States?      President Trump’s actions and comments repeatedly demonstrate a failure to grasp matters of critical importance to our national security. His announcement contradicts the Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman’s assessment, the International Atomic Energy Agency’s assessment, and whatever assessment he made that prompted him to twice certify Iran’s compliance this year. Congress must not vote to reapply sanctions suspended under the JCPOA and risk compounding the damage done by this reckless decision.
